title: Presentations
text:
MCEVBD job interview
I gave this  presentation  as part of my job interview for my current job at the MCEVBD. This presentation was made with LaTeX. The raw code can be found see here and downloaded here.
PhD defense talk
I gave this  presentation  as part of my PhD defense at the University of Zurich. This presentation was made with LaTeX. The raw code can be found here.

title: Publications list
text:
1. Jansen, D. A. The contribution of floodplains to the ecology of large herbivores. (University of Wageningen, 2013).


2. Jansen, D. A. Self-organising spatial patterns in mussel beds. (University of Wageningen, 2013).


3. Jansen, D. A. Diet selection of goats: - a feeding trial experiment. (University of Wageningen, 2013).


4. Jansen, D. A., Langevelde, F. van, Boer, W. F. de & Kirkman, K. P. Optimisation or satiation, testing diet selection rules in goats. Small Ruminant Research 73, 160–168 (2007).


5. Jansen, D. A., Cant, M. A. & Manser, M. B. Segmental concatenation of individual signatures and context cues in banded mongoose (mungos mungo) close calls. BMC biology 10, 1–11 (2012).


6. Jansen, D. A., Cant, M. A. & Manser, M. B. Testing for vocal individual discrimination in adult banded mongooses. Journal of Zoology 291, 171–177 (2013).


7. Jansen, D. A. Vocal communication in the banded mongoose (mungos mungo). (University of Zurich, 2013).


8. Manser, M. B. et al. Vocal complexity in meerkats and other mongoose species. 46, 281–310 (2014).


9. Townsend, S. W. et al. Exorcising g rice’s ghost: An empirical approach to studying intentional communication in animals. Biological Reviews 92, 1427–1433 (2017).


10. Akinyi, M. Y. et al. Costs and drivers of helminth parasite infection in wild female baboons. Journal of Animal Ecology 88, 1029–1043 (2019).


11. Habig, B. et al. Multi-scale predictors of parasite risk in wild male savanna baboons (papio cynocephalus). Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology 73, 1–16 (2019).


12. Levy, E. J. et al. A comparison of dominance rank metrics reveals multiple competitive landscapes in an animal society. Proceedings of the Royal Society B 287, 20201013 (2020).


13. Grieneisen, L. et al. Heritability of the gut microbiome in wild baboons (papio cynocephalus). in American journal of primatology vol. 82 (WILEY 111 RIVER ST, HOBOKEN 07030-5774, NJ USA, 2020).


14. Grieneisen, L. et al. Gut microbiome heritability is nearly universal but environmentally contingent. Science 373, 181–186 (2021).


15. Björk, J. R. et al. Synchrony and idiosyncrasy in the gut microbiome of wild baboons. Nature ecology & evolution 6, 955–964 (2022).


16. Paietta, E. N. et al. Troubled waters: Water availability drives human-baboon encounters in a protected, semi-arid landscape. Biological Conservation 274, 109740 (2022).


17. Gordon, J. B., Jansen, D. A., Learn, N. H. & Alberts, S. C. Ordinal dominance rank assignments: Protocol for the amboseli baboon research project. Avaialable at: https://amboselibaboons. nd. edu/downloads/, Accessed Feb 23, 2023 (2022).


18. Roche, K. E. et al. Universal gut microbial relationships in the gut microbiome of wild baboons. Elife 12, e83152 (2023).


19. Weibel, C. J. et al. Using non-invasive behavioral and physiological data to measure biological age in wild baboons. GeroScience (2024) doi:10.1007/s11357-024-01157-5.


20. Jansen, D. A., Warutere, J. K., Tung, J., Alberts, S. C. & Archie, E. A. Early-life paternal relationships predict adult female survival in wild baboons. Proceedings of the Royal Society B xxx, (in press).

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (1)

Keep an as raw as possible version
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (1)

Keep an as raw as possible version
Consider making your original data file read-only




keep in a ‘save’ format
Not excel format - transferring between platforms can cause an issue (e.g. dates)
csv, tsv, maybe text






Don’t make changes to this raw data
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (2)

Content of columns in correct data type and units

character (e.g, “a”, “swc”)
numeric (real or decimal) (e.g, 2, 2.0)
logical (FALSE, TRUE)
integer (e.g, 2L, as.integer(3))
complex (e.g, 1 + 0i, 1 + 4i) <- These can be annoying




R sees logical as 0/1 (FALSE/TRUE). This can be handy during coding.
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (3)

Try to have content of columns in correct data type and units
An example why this can is important
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (4)

Use a scripted program not only for analysis, but also for data cleaning and data wrangling

title: Good data practices
text:

Use a scripted program not only for analysis, but also for data cleaning and data wrangling
reproducible
Keep raw version safe !!!
Lyric: “House E used pesticides and should be excluded for this study”


 raw_data_wide %>% 
  select(-House_E) %>%    ## The owners used pesticides during the trials
  knitr::kable(digits = 1) %>% 
  kable_classic(full_width = F, html_font = "Cambria")
      # flextable::flextable() %>% 
      # flextable::colformat_double(digits = 1)

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (4)

Use a scripted program not only for analysis, but also for data cleaning and data wrangling
reproducible
Keep raw version safe !!!
Lyric: “House E used pesticides and should be excluded for this study”
A few months later…




Lyric: “I changed my mind about house_E”






“Sorry I deleted that data” versus “Let me rerun code”

title: Good data practices
text:
Wide format versus long format



wide often easier for recording
long often required for analysis

Tip


You know details of project and data structure (at this moment), but what about future you or others.
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Data documentation (2)

README

one per dataset
provide a title for the dataset
brief description per column
publicly available data may need more details
https://guides.lib.uci.edu/datamanagement/readme

Metadata

often 1 per study
information does generally not change

e.g. details on study sites

data about data




https://datadryad.org/stash/best_practices https://data.research.cornell.edu/content/readme
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Naming

Use descriptive names for folders, files and variables




Understandable but not to long

m1 versus glm_count_full
data versus tick_counts_EA










Tip


While a computer will ultimately run your code, it’ll be read by humans, so write code intended for humans!
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Naming



Be aware on naming rules of programs

Avoid special characters ($, @, *)
Avoid name of functions
No spaces !!
Case-sensitive (e.g. R) versus case insensitive (SQL)
R (and many other languages) names can’t start with numbers and does not like spaces
‘car speed in miles per hour’ versus ‘car speed (mph)’ versus car_speed_mph’
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
section: How to deal with R (programming) errors
text:
How to deal with R (programming) errors

don’t get frustrated by error messages
read the error message
google the error message
google solutions or use ChatGPT
trial and error

it works –> go back to your analysis

error -> go back to 1.
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text: Examples of problems last year

title: Good data practices
text:
Blank versus 0

0 means that you did not find tick
blank could mean several things

You looked for ticks, but did not find any.
You did not look for ticks so you don’t know how many ticks there are.
Computers will see blanks as NA (i.e. you don’t know).


Example why this is an important difference
So please pay attention so I can avoid this





and be

title: blah blah
text:
this is how to print a flextable in a R Markdown document


library(flextable)
ft <- flextable(head(mtcars))
ft <- autofit(ft)
ft

mpgcyldisphpdratwtqsecvsamgearcarb21.061601103.902.62016.46014421.061601103.902.87517.02014422.84108933.852.32018.61114121.462581103.083.21519.44103118.783601753.153.44017.02003218.162251052.763.46020.221031

I am data scientist at the [Midwest Center of Excellence for Vector-Borne Disease (MCEVBD)] (https://mcevbd.wisc.edu/). I have a broad experience in behavioral research, database management, statistical modeling, and data visualization. I enjoy being a resource for my colleagues and providing advice on experimental design, statistical modeling, coding, and research reproducibility. Prior to joining the center, I worked as a research scientist at the University of Notre Dame and the Amboseli Baboon Research Project.

I am data scientist at the [Midwest Center of Excellence for Vector-Borne Disease (MCEVBD)] (https://mcevbd.wisc.edu/). I have a broad experience in behavioral research, database management, statistical modeling, and data visualization. I enjoy being a resource for my colleagues and providing advice on experimental design, statistical modeling, coding, and research reproducibility. Prior to joining the center, I worked as a research scientist at the University of Notre Dame and the Amboseli Baboon Research Project.

Education
University of Zurich , Switzerland PhD in Animal communication | Sep 2009 - Apr 2013
Wageningen University, Netherlands MsC in Forest and Nature Management - Ecology | Aug 2003 - June 2005
Wageningen University, Netherlands BSc in Forest and Nature Management | Aug 2000 - June 2003
Click here for my Resume or CV

Add page and line numbers
Send to PIs

Send to co-authors (give them a heads-up)

Decide on journal

scope

similar work

text:

Submission

Cover letter

Cover letters

Plos Biology
Plos one

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Submission

Cover letter
Have everything ready. Often specific formats it needs to be submitted

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Receiving reviewer comments

Good reviewers make your paper better
If rejected still look at comments and do something with them
Very often major or minor revisions needed

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Receiving reviewer comments

Revisions required

Read all comments first
Share with co-authors (also ask if you need help with specific comments)
Respond to all comments and keep track of changes
Generally a limited turn around period
Jansen et al paper

Rejected

Still, read all the comments

Why was the paper rejected?

Generally, still, revise paper
Habig et al paper

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Respond to reviewer comments

Respond to all comments

Point by point
Track changes on the document
All co-authors should read responses and agree
Include a cover letter to the editor
Major revision Jansen et al BMC paper

title: Introduction into peer review process
text:
Proofing paper

Paper is accepted
Copy editors will format paper They are probrably not scientists
Jansen et al BMC paper proofing request

First time you see your final paper :-)

Jansen et al BMC paper proof document

Read whole paper
Check details

references
figures and tables (captions)
scientific names and notations
author names and affiliations

Jansen et al BMC paper comments to proof

title: Introduction into git
text: What is version control

title: Introduction into git
text:
What is version control

Keep track and saves all you changes to code
Good backup source
Easier to fix mistakes
Code is open and easy to share
Multiple people working on the same code

title: Introduction into git
text:
What is Git

Git is a version control system that allows developers to track changes in their code
installed on your own computer
controlled through mostly terminal

but e.g. Rstudio have systems to make it easier

there are alternatives but git is most common (at least in science)

title: Introduction into git
text:
What is GitHub

GitHub is a web-based hosting service for git repositories.
Enables you to store and share code for different projects
More advanced

Github actions
Github pages
Together they can e.g. build and host a webpage (e.g. this presentation).

title: Introduction into git
text: Let’s have some fun !!

title: Introduction into git
text:
Let’s have some fun
Sorry I forgot I am in an mosquito lab

title: Introduction into git
text:

Make an account

https://github.com/signup

Install git

https://github.com/git-guides/install-git

Github student account
private repositories

title: Introduction into git
text:
Make a repository

Method 1 (easy)

Create repository on github
https://github.com

Method 2 (harder)

use Git Repo

Create a repository from command line
Not today

title: Introduction into git
text:
Terminal

‘Easy’ start with git bash

https://education.github.com/git-cheat-sheet-education.pdf
Let’s go to the terminal.

title: Introduction into git
text:
Terminal
echo "# training_repo" >> README.md
git init
git add README.md
git commit -m "first commit"
git branch -M main
git remote add origin git@github.com:david-awam-jansen/training_repo.git
git push -u origin main

text:
Terminal
git status
git add
git commit

title: Introduction into git
text:
Naming



Be aware on naming rules of programs

Avoid special characters ($, @, *)
Avoid name of functions
No spaces !!
Case-sensitive (e.g. R) versus case insensitive (SQL)
R (and many other languages) names can’t start with numbers and does not like spaces
‘car speed in miles per hour’ versus ‘car speed (mph)’ versus car_speed_mph’

title: Good data practices
text:
Import
Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished presentation. To learn more about Quarto presentations see https://quarto.org/docs/presentations/.

title: Good data practices
text:
Bullets
When you click the Render button a document will be generated that includes:

Content authored with markdown
Output from executable code

title: Good data practices
text:
Code
When you click the Render button a presentation will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:


[1] 2

title: Research reproducibility
text: Folder organization

title: Research reproducibility
text:
Other sources
Noble WS. A quick guide to organizing computational biology projects. PLoS Comput Biol. 2009 Jul;5(7):e1000424. doi: 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1000424. http://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1000424
Casadevall A, Ellis LM, Davies EW, McFall-Ngai M, Fang FC. A Framework for Improving the Quality of Research in the Biological Sciences. MBio. 2016 Aug 30;7(4). pii: e01256-16. doi: 10.1128/mBio.01256-16. http://mbio.asm.org/content/7/4/e01256-16.long
Ravel J, Wommack KE. All hail reproducibility in microbiome research. Microbiome. 2014 Mar 7;2(1):8. doi: 10.1186/2049-2618-2-8. https://microbiomejournal.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/2049-2618-2-8

title: David Jansen
text: The site is created with Rstudio and Quarto (https://quarto.org/docs/websites). It uses a Docker container to manage R packages and is maintained through github actions.
